title: The ultimate guide to Martech | Austin Hay (Reforge, Ramp, Runway)
key_insights: Tools are meant to solve problems - don't pick tools based on familiarity, focus on the specific problem you're solving
Think 'build AND buy' instead of 'build vs buy' - combine third-party tools with custom solutions for optimal results
Set up attribution infrastructure from day one by collecting first and last touch UTM parameters, even if you start with simple attribution models
MarTech becomes necessary around 100-150 employees when village-style tool management no longer scales
Use the PPS framework: Problem, People, System - understand the problem and people involved before jumping to system solutions
Design systems with 1-2 year future state in mind to avoid costly migrations later
Probabilistic attribution is becoming essential as deterministic matching becomes harder with iOS 14+ and cookie restrictions

guest_background.current_role: Head of Marketing Technology at Ramp

topics_discussed: Definition and role of marketing technology
When to hire a MarTech person vs relying on growth team
B2C vs B2B technology stack differences
Customer Data Platforms (CDPs) and reverse ETLs
Multi-touch attribution setup and best practices
Impact of iOS 14 and privacy changes on attribution
Interview questions and hiring criteria for MarTech roles
Recommended technology stacks for different business types
Emerging platforms like Threads and Reddit advertising
Email marketing tool evolution (Customer.io to Braze)
Cross-functional collaboration with product, engineering, and growth teams
memorable_quotes: Tools are just meant to solve problems
From 2010 to 2020, we had the golden years of deterministic matching where it was very easy to run an ad and understand with precision who installed the app. You can't do that anymore.
Think gray - don't decide for as long as you possibly can before you have to decide
frameworks_mentioned: Build AND Buy (not Build vs Buy)
Multi-touch Attribution (MTA) vs Mixed Media Modeling (MMM)
summary: Austin Hay provides a comprehensive guide to marketing technology (MarTech), covering when to hire MarTech professionals, how to structure growth technology stacks, and tactical advice for attribution, tool selection, and cross-functional collaboration. The episode is packed with specific recommendations for B2B vs B2C companies and practical frameworks for making better technology decisions.
